definitions.definition: To move nearer to the point of perspective .
examples: She’ll be coming round the mountain when she comes the wrong way [ … ]
I called the dog, but she wouldn't come .
Stop dawdling and come here!
Hold on, I'll come in a second.
You should ask the doctor to come to your house.

subdefinitions.definition: To move toward the object that is the focus of the sentence.
examples: No-one can find Bertie Wooster when his aunts come to visit.
Hundreds of thousands of people come to Disneyland every year.

subdefinitions.definition: To move toward the agent or subject of the main clause.
examples: King Cnut couldn't stop the tide coming .
He threw the boomerang, which came right back to him.

subdefinitions.definition: To move toward an unstated agent.
examples: The butler should come when called.

definitions.definition: To appear ; to manifest itself; to cause a reaction by manifesting.
examples: The pain in his leg comes and goes.
The news came as a shock.

definitions.definition: To begin (to have an opinion or feeling).
examples: We came to believe that he was not so innocent after all.
She came to think of that country as her home.

definitions.definition: To do something by chance or unintentionally .
examples: Could you tell me how the document came to be discovered?

definitions.definition: To take a position relative to something else in a sequence .
examples: Which letter comes before Y?   Winter comes after autumn.

definitions.definition: To achieve orgasm ; to cum ; to ejaculate .
examples: She came after a few minutes.
Come in me!

definitions.definition: To become butter by being churned .
To approach or reach a state of being or accomplishment.
examples: They came very close to leaving on time.   His test scores came close to perfect.
One of the screws came loose, and the skateboard fell apart.

definitions.definition: To take a particular approach or point of view in regard to something.
examples: He came to SF literature a confirmed technophile, and nothing made him happier than to read a manuscript thick with imaginary gizmos and whatzits.

definitions.definition: To become , to turn out to be.
examples: He was a dream come true.

definitions.definition: To be supplied, or made available; to exist.
examples: He's as tough as they come .
Our milkshakes come in vanilla, strawberry and chocolate flavours.
A new sports car doesn't come cheap.

definitions.definition: To carry through; to succeed in.
examples: You can't come any tricks here.
This kind of accident comes when you are careless.

definitions.definition: To have as an origin , originate .

subdefinitions.definition: To have a certain social background .
To be or have been a resident or native.
examples: Where did you come from?

subdefinitions.definition: To have been brought up by or employed by.
examples: She comes from a good family.
He comes from a disreputable legal firm.

subdefinitions.definition: To begin (at a certain location); to radiate or stem (from).
examples: The river comes from Bear Lake.
Where does this road come from?

definitions.label_groups: intransitive , with from or sometimes of

definitions.definition: To pretend to be; to behave in the manner of; to assume the role of.
examples: Don’t come the innocent victim. We all know who’s to blame here.

main_definition: ( intransitive ) To move nearer to the point of perspective .
secondary_definitions: ( intransitive ) To appear ; to manifest itself; to cause a reaction by manifesting.
( with an infinitive ) To begin (to have an opinion or feeling).
( with an infinitive ) To do something by chance or unintentionally .
( intransitive ) To take a position relative to something else in a sequence .
( intransitive , often vulgar , slang ) To achieve orgasm ; to cum ; to ejaculate .
( intransitive , of milk ) To become butter by being churned .
( copulative , figuratively ) To approach or reach a state of being or accomplishment.
( figuratively , with to ) To take a particular approach or point of view in regard to something.
( copulative , fossil word ) To become , to turn out to be.
( intransitive ) To be supplied, or made available; to exist.
( slang ) To carry through; to succeed in.
( intransitive , with from or sometimes of ) To have as an origin , originate .
( transitive , informal ) To pretend to be; to behave in the manner of; to assume the role of.
